metadata.title: Mapping Images to Scene Graphs with Permutation-Invariant Structured Prediction
metadata.author: Roei Herzig, Moshiko Raboh, Gal Chechik, Jonathan Berant, Amir Globerson
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: Machine understanding of complex images is a key goal of artificial intelligence. One challenge underlying this task is that visual scenes contain multiple interrelated objects, and that global context plays an important role in interpreting the scene. A natural modeling framework for capturing such effects is structured prediction, which optimizes over complex labels, while modeling within-label interactions. However, it is unclear what principles should guide the design of a structured prediction model that utilizes the power of deep learning components. Here we propose a design principle for such architectures that follows from a natural requirement of permutation invariance. We prove a necessary and sufficient characterization for architectures that follow this invariance, and discuss its implication on model design. Finally, we show that the resulting model achieves new state-of-the-art results on the Visual Genome scene-graph labeling benchmark, outperforming all recent approaches.

highlights: Understanding the semantics of a complex visual scene is a fundamental problem in machine perception
While numerous inference algorithms exist for this setup, including belief propagation (BP) and mean field, here we develop a framework for a deep labeling algorithm
We evaluated our approach on Visual Genome (VG) [15], a dataset with 108,077 images annotated with bounding boxes, entities and relations
All graph-permutation invariant variants performs well, with LINGUISTIC outperforming all baselines for SGCls and being comparable to the state-of-the-art model for PredCls
We presented a deep learning approach to structured prediction, which constrains the architecture to be invariant to structurally identical inputs
There may be cases where the invariant structure is unknown and should be discovered from data, which is related to work on lifting graphical models [4]
key_statements: Understanding the semantics of a complex visual scene is a fundamental problem in machine perception

We describe a model that satisfies the permutation invariance property, and show that it achieves state-of-the-art results on the competitive Visual Genome benchmark [15], demonstrating the power of our new design principle
It is worthwhile to rethink the architecture of structured prediction models, and consider models that map inputs x to outputs y directly without explicitly maximizing a score function

We present such an approach and consider a natural question: what should be the properties of a deep neural network used for structured prediction.
3 Permutation-Invariant Structured Prediction
While numerous inference algorithms exist for this setup, including belief propagation (BP) and mean field, here we develop a framework for a deep labeling algorithm
We show that any F satisfying the conditions of Theorem 1 is graph-permutation invariant
Attention can be naturally implemented in our graph-permutation invariant characterization, and we provide a full derivation for this implementation in the appendix
We evaluated our approach on Visual Genome (VG) [15], a dataset with 108,077 images annotated with bounding boxes, entities and relations

We compare four variants of our graph-permutation invariant approach with the reported results of four baselines that are currently the state-of-the-art on various scene graph prediction problems: 1) LU ET AL., 2016 [19]: This work leverages word embeddings to fine-tune the likelihood of predicted relations. 2) XU ET AL, 2017 [29]: This model passes messages between entities and relations, and iteratively refines the feature map used for prediction. 3) NEWELL & DENG, 2017 [21]: The PIXEL2GRAPH model uses associative embeddings [22] to produce a full graph from the image. 4) YANG ET AL., 2018 [30]: The GRAPH R-CNN model uses object-relation regularities to sparsify and reason over scene graphs. 5) ZELLERS ET AL., 2017 [32]: The NEURALMOTIF method encodes global context for
All graph-permutation invariant variants performs well, with LINGUISTIC outperforming all baselines for SGCls and being comparable to the state-of-the-art model for PredCls
We presented a deep learning approach to structured prediction, which constrains the architecture to be invariant to structurally identical inputs
There may be cases where the invariant structure is unknown and should be discovered from data, which is related to work on lifting graphical models [4]
summary: Understanding the semantics of a complex visual scene is a fundamental problem in machine perception.
Structured prediction models typically define a score function s(x, y) that quantifies how well a label assignment y is compatible with an input x.

Scored-based methods in structured prediction define a function s(x, y) that quantifies the degree to which y is compatible with x, and infer a label by maximizing s(x, y) [e.g., see 2, 7, 16, 20, 28].
It is worthwhile to rethink the architecture of structured prediction models, and consider models that map inputs x to outputs y directly without explicitly maximizing a score function.
We can view inference as a black-box that takes node-dependent and edge-dependent inputs and returns a label y, even without an explicit score function s(x, y).
A graph labeling function F : (V, E) → Y is a function whose input is an ordered set of node features V = [z1, .
We provide our key definition of a function whose output is invariant to permutations of the input.
This results in a recurrent architecture, which we use in our scene graph model.

The invariance we consider is much less restrictive: the architecture does not need to be invariant to all permutations of singleton and pairwise features, just those consistent with a graph re-labeling.

NeuralMotif [32], currently the state-of-the-art model for scene graph prediction on Visual Genome, employs an RNN that provides global context by sequentially reading the independent predictions for each entity and relation and refines those predictions.
We evaluate the GPI approach on the motivating task of this paper, inferring scene graphs from images (Figure 1).

The input is an image annotated with a set of bounding boxes for the entities in the image.2 The goal is to label each bounding box with the correct entity category and every pair of entities with their relation, such that they form a coherent scene graph.
The network αent takes as input the outputs of φent for all neighbors of an entity, and uses the attention mechanism described above to output a vector of dimension n2.

We compare four variants of our GPI approach with the reported results of four baselines that are currently the state-of-the-art on various scene graph prediction problems: 1) LU ET AL., 2016 [19]: This work leverages word embeddings to fine-tune the likelihood of predicted relations.
Capturing high-order motifs in scene graphs, and the BASELINE outputs the entities and relations distributions without using the global context.
It would be interesting to explore algorithms that discover and use such symmetries for deep structured prediction
headline: We propose a design principle for such architectures that follows from a natural requirement of permutation invariance
